title: What is the scope of food processing technology diploma courses? - Quora

response.answer_text: My answer will pertain to 4-year degrees within land grant universities in the US in regards to food processing… The general curriculum gives background in nutrition as well as several courses in food science, including, food processing. Larger universities, such as Ohio State, have pilot plants with numerous pieces food processing equipment that can be demonstrated by making actual products. This is usually done in group projects where you select a product to make and go through all the necessary steps to produce it. Classes also include labs that demonstrate basic unit operations of food processing such as heat transfer. Other labs may focus on the evaluation of foods using analytical lab equipment or sensory analysis. Finally, there are classes that give you a solid base of knowledge in food science, such as food chemistry, sensory science, food microbiology, food packaging, food regulations & operations management. On campus, you have the opportunity to join groups such as the Food Science Club and gain membership to the IFT (Institute of Food Technologists) where you can network with food professionals, search jobs & stay up to date with the latest in food science.

You can apply for jobs as Quality assurance inspector, food processor, food auditor, food scientist etc. Through food tech programs. These jobs are not highly paid abroad and usually confined in factory settings where food is processed, shipped, stored or sold. You can also find jobs in restaurants, community kitchens, food franchises etc. All the best.
